metadata.title: Individual and temporal variation in pathogen load predicts long- 1 term impacts of an emerging infectious disease

abstract.text: Emerging infectious diseases increasingly threaten wildlife populations. Most studies focus 27 on managing short-term epidemic properties, such as controlling early outbreaks. Predicting 28 long-term endemic characteristics with limited retrospective data is more challenging. We 29 used individual-based modelling informed by individual variation in pathogen load and 30 transmissibility to predict long-term impacts of a lethal, transmissible cancer on Tasmanian 31 devil (Sarcophilus harrisii) populations. For this, we employed Approximate Bayesian 32 Computation to identify model scenarios that best matched known epidemiological and 33 demographic system properties derived from ten years of data after disease emergence, 34 enabling us to forecast future system dynamics. We show that the dramatic devil population 35 declines observed thus far are likely attributable to transient dynamics. Only 21% of 36 matching scenarios led to devil extinction within 100 years following devil facial tumour 37 disease (DFTD) introduction, whereas DFTD faded out in 57% of simulations. In the 38 remaining 22% of simulations, disease and host coexisted for at least 100 years, usually with 39 long-period oscillations. Our findings show that pathogen extirpation or host-pathogen 40 coexistence are much more likely than the DFTD-induced devil extinction, with crucial 41 management ramifications. Accounting for individual-level disease progression and the long-42 term outcome of devil-DFTD interactions at the population-level, our findings suggest that 43 immediate management interventions are unlikely to be necessary to ensure the persistence of 44

Tasmanian devil populations. This is because strong population declines of devils after 45 disease emergence do not necessarily translate into long-term population declines at 46 equilibria. Our modelling approach is widely applicable to other host-pathogen systems to 47 predict disease impact beyond transient dynamics.

FIGREF0.text: diseases most often attract attention because their initial impacts on host 56 populations are frequently severe (de Castro and Bolker 2005, Smith et al. 2009). Following 57 the initial epidemic and transient dynamic behaviour, long-term outcomes include pathogen 58 fadeout, host extinction, or long-term endemicity with varying impacts on the host population 59 size (Hastings 2004, Benton et al. 2006, Cazelles and Hales 2006). Predicting which of these 60 long-term outcomes may occur on the basis of initial transient dynamics is very challenging 61 and conclusions about possible disease effects on population viability based on early 62 epidemic dynamics can be misleading. 63 Nevertheless, predicting the long-term consequences of an infectious disease as early 64 as possible in the emergence process is important for management. If the disease has a high 65 likelihood of ultimately leading to host extinction, then strategies such as stamping out 66 infection by removing all potentially infectious individuals may be justifiable, despite short-67 term impacts on the host species and ethical considerations (McCallum and Hocking 2005).

However, by 81 definition, it does not include density dependent factors and is therefore sometimes 82 insufficient to predict the long-term consequences of disease introduction into a new 83 population. 84 Most existing models for infectious disease are based around compartmental 85 Susceptible -Exposed -Infected -Recovered epidemiological models (S-E-I-R), which rely 86 on a strict assumption of homogeneity of individuals within compartments (Anderson and 87 May 1991). There is a parallel literature for macroparasitic infections, which assumes both a 88 stationary distribution of parasites amongst hosts and that parasite burden is determined by 89 the number of infective stages the host has encountered (Anderson and May 1978). For many 90 pathogens, pathogen load on (or inside) an individual typically changes following infection as 91 a result of within-host processes, causing temporal shifts in transmission and host mortality 92 rates. For example, the volume of transmissible tumours on Tasmanian devils (Sarcophilus 93 harrisii) increases through time, with measurable impacts on survival (Wells et al. 2017) and 94 likely temporal increases in transmission probability to uninfected devils that bite into the 95 growing tumour mass (Hamede et al. 2013). Similarly, increasing burden of the amphibian 96 chytrid fungus Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis on individual frogs after infection limits host 97 survival, with important consequences for disease spread and population dynamics (Briggs et 98 al. 2010, Wilber et al. 2016). FIGREF3.text: 109 facial tumour disease (DFTD), a transmissible cancer, on Tasmanian devil populations. 110 DFTD is a recently emerged infectious disease, first detected in 1996 in north-eastern 111 Tasmania (Hawkins et al. 2006). It is caused by a clonal cancerous cell line, which is 112 transmitted by direct transfer of live tumour cells when devils bite each other (Pearse and 113 Swift 2006, Jones et al. 2008, Hamede et al. 2013). DFTD is nearly always fatal and largely 114 affects individuals that are otherwise the fittest in the population (Wells et al. 2017). 115 Population declines to very low numbers concomitant with the frequency-dependent 116 transmission of DFTD led to predictions of devil extinctions, based on compartmental 117 epidemiological models (McCallum et al. 2009, Hamede et al. 2012).

FIGREF17.text: 302 observational data at our case study site (West Pencil Pine), are consistent with observations 303 now emerging from long-term field studies of the dynamics of Tasmanian devils and DFTD 304 (Lazenby et al. 2018). No Tasmanian devil population has yet become extinctand 305 populations persist, albeit in low numbers, where disease has been present the longest (e.g., at 306 wukalina/Mount William National Park and at Freycinet, where DFTD emerged, 307 respectively, at least 21 and 17 years ago) (Epstein et al. 2016). Also, a considerable decline 308 in DFTD prevalence has been observed in recent years at Freycinet (Sebastien Comte, 309 unpublished data). These study sites did not contribute to the fitting of our model and at least 310 to some extent constitute an independent validation and test of the model predictions. Our 311 modelling results suggest that observed population dynamics of devils and DFTD do not 312 require evolutionary changes, although there is evidence of rapid evolution in disease-313 burdened devil populations (Epstein et al. 2016) similar to rapid evolution in other vertebrates 314 when subjected to intense selection pressure (Christie et al. 2016, Campbell-Staton et al. 315 2017). 316 One of the differences between earlier models and those we present here is the 317 inclusion of tumour growth, with mortality and transmission rates that depend on individual 318 disease burden. Inclusion of burden-dependent dynamics results in additional and 319 qualitatively different time delays than those incorporated in previous models. Tumours take 320 time to grow before they have a major impact on host survival and become highly infectious 321 (Hamede et al. 2017, Wells et al. 2017). This slows the spread of DFTD and its impact on 322 devil population fluctuations. It also means that parameters estimated from field data, without McCallum et al. 2009). Our models suggest that documented dramatic population declines 325 during the first 10 years or so of the DFTD epizootic may represent just the first peak of a 326 classical epidemic (Bailey 1975). Long-term predictions from our models suggest, however, 327 that DFTD is a slow burning disease with population changes governed by long-term 328 oscillations. 329 It is well known, both from simple Lotka-Volterra models and from a range of 330 empirical studies, that consumer-resource interactions have a propensity to cycle, driven by 331 the time delays inherent in these systems (Murdoch et al. 2003). Disease burden-dependent 332 demographic and epidemiological parameters, together with burden growth within the host, 333 add additional time delays, both lengthening any oscillations and increasing the likelihood 334 that they will be maintained in the longer term. Apparently, such time-delays increase the 335 probability of host-pathogen coexistence, similar to predator-prey dynamics, rather than host 336 or pathogen extirpation. Grounded in theory and a reasonable body of modelling studies of 337 other wildlife diseases, disease-induced population extinction appears to be more generally an 338 exception rather than the rule, unless host populations are very small, or unless there are 339 reservoir species that are tolerant of infection (de Castro and Bolker 2005).

FIGREF18.text: we apply herecoupling the flexibility of individual-based models to account 342 for heterogeneity in disease burden and space use with Approximate Bayesian Computation 343 to match model outcomes with available empirical evidence -offers considerable potential 344 for making predictions regarding the population dynamics for other emerging diseases (Toni 345 et al. 2009, Beaumont 2010, Johnson and Briggs 2011, Wells et al. 2015). A fundamental 346 problem in applying modelling approaches to forecast the outcome of emerging infectious 347 disease epidemics is the need to estimate parameter values based on empirical data derived relatively early stages of an epizootic, in the absence of retrospective knowledge 349 (Heesterbeek et al. 2015, Ferguson et al. 2016). Examples include estimating R0 for SARS 350 (Lipsitch et al. 2003) and for the 2014-2015 Ebola epidemic in West Africa (Whitty et al. 351 2014, WHO Ebola Response Team 2014) among others (LaDeau et al. 2011). In most of 352 these cases, the objective is to estimate parameters associated with the growth phase of the 353 epidemic to assess the effectiveness of interventions such as vaccination. The task we have 354 addressed in this paper is even more challengingseeking to predict the long-term endemic 355 behaviour of a pathogen that is currently still in the early stages of emergence. We suggest 356 that management efforts to maintain devil populations in the face of DFTD should be guided 357 by our changing understanding of the long-term dynamics of the DFTD epidemic. 358 Management efforts in wild populations that solely aim to combat the impact of DFTD can 359 be counterproductive if they disrupt long-term eco-evolutionary dynamics that may 360 eventually lead to endemicity with stable devil populations. Our ability to predict future 361 outcomes in the absence of management actions require some caution as we cannot fully 362 exclude the possibility that DFTD can cause local population extinctions once populations are 363 small, warranting future research. While our findings emphasize the importance of 364 accounting for individual tumour load for accurate prediction and epidemiological modelling 365 of DFTD dynamics, our inability to uncover the exact role of devil spatial proximity on 366 disease transmission means that further research is necessary to understand relevant factors in 367 disease spread.

The additional time dependence introduced by within-host pathogen growth can have a major 102 influence on the dynamics of host-pathogen interactions as uncovered by nested models that link within-and between-host processes of disease dynamics (Gilchrist and Coombs 2006, Mideo et al. 2008). Such dynamics are poorly captured by conventional compartmental and 105 macroparasite model structures. Thus, connecting across the scales of within-and betweenhost dynamics remains a key challenge in understanding infectious disease epidemiology 107 (Gog et al. 2015).
